text:
Hey content folks :wave:  I want to share a lesson I learned in case it helps you all make more $$$ and grow in your careers _like it did mine_ :wink: 

As a content maker, you probably take a lot of pride in your work—the smooth flow of an argument, the lovely turns of phrase, the witty one-liners. But your bosses or clients _don’t care about any of that._ 

They don’t (usually) care if it’s a podcast, a book, or a blog post → these are TACTICS. What they expect to hear is how any content you produce will solve a business challenge → this is STRATEGY.

…and you make yourself way more employable and valuable (think: $) if you move from ‘just’ delivering like a tactician to also thinking like a strategist. Instead of jumping straight into a tactic (“we should have a blog!” or “let’s get on Clubhouse!“), thinking like a strategist requires you to first understand what’s going on and determine where you want to go. And that usually happens when you start *asking the right questions in the right order*.

I made the slide deck below to show you what I mean & the kinds of questions you can start asking + *<https://contentfolks.substack.com/p/content-marketing-diagnosis-strategy-tactics|here is some more context>* if you want the behind-the-scenes story of how I learned this lesson.

Hope this gets you a promotion or raise some time soon! :wink:

…and you make yourself way more employable and valuable (think: $) if you move from ‘just’ delivering like a tactician to also thinking like a strategist. text:
Absolutely, I do a lot of content creation for B2B SaaS & tech companies. Blogs, white papers, emails, etc.

I'm trained as a content strategist but with many clients (who may not be aware I could help with strategy) I wasn't privy to their strategy which makes it tough to help. You effectively get reduced to an order taker.

When you know where the biz is headed, you can make strategic recommendations instead of just pushing for execution work.

text: <@U01GLCVCT89> with the caveat that this is highly dependent on the company(ies) you work for, usually a business challenge could be something like acquiring new customers, retaining existing ones/avoiding churn, lowering acquisition costs, etc. If you read <https://contentfolks.substack.com/p/content-marketing-diagnosis-strategy-tactics|the example I linked to>, you can see that the company I was hired by was struggling with (organic) customer acquisition and needed a different way to get their name out + acquire customers. Make sense?

text:
Hello friends! Career question about individual contributors and making moolah. :moneybag:

I have been a content strategy manager 5 years, the last 3 spent at a rapidly growing tech SaaS company. I built our content ecosystem from the ground up and it has been very successful. So that’s good.

I’ve recently decided for my mental and emotional wellbeing to step back from management and become an individual contributor / producer / internal content consultant for our company.

My manager is in full support because he knows that where I really shine is creation and I will 100% bring value because I always do.

The trick is, we’ve never seen this kind of structure before on a content team. I am the most senior person on a our team, I built the thing, but now I don’t want to own it. Any advice / experience with this?

elements.text: Hello friends! Career question about individual contributors and making moolah.

I have been a content strategy manager 5 years, the last 3 spent at a rapidly growing tech SaaS company. I built our content ecosystem from the ground up and it has been very successful. So that’s good.

I’ve recently decided for my mental and emotional wellbeing to step back from management and become an individual contributor / producer / internal content consultant for our company.

My manager is in full support because he knows that where I really shine is creation and I will 100% bring value because I always do.

The trick is, we’ve never seen this kind of structure before on a content team. I am the most senior person on a our team, I built the thing, but now I don’t want to own it. Any advice / experience with this?

text:
Thank you for this post. I’ve been increasingly thinking about doing the same thing. Part of me is like, “you’re insane, why walk away from running the thing you built up?”

Will be following along. I thought I was alone!

text: One more voice following along—I am still really passionate about leadership/management but long term, have always had a curiosity about serving as an “internal consultant” of sorts. (And let’s be honest, 2020 was not the easiest year to be a people manager.) Looking forward to hearing others’ thoughts!

text:
The only advice I have is—hire or promote your replacement, and enjoy your new life as an IC :slightly_smiling_face:

It’s not uncommon for people to progress and give ‘their baby’ off to someone else. After a few years, my former manager/lead felt more suited to an IC position and offloaded some of the work to me + others on the team. An interim lead was found, reporting lines were scrambled for a bit, but ultimately everybody enjoyed the new pace and all was well! You might even find that the ‘thing’ you built will be strengthened and improved in someone else’s hands.

text: Congrats on your success and for pursuing what works best for you! I agree with Fio and Victoria. For me, when I followed this same path a couple of years ago, I found it easier for me to exit the company after helping find and groom my replacement. I found it hard to let go of my baby, even though I knew it was best, and once I discovered that was difficult for me, I made the decision to help find my replacement, help train her, then gracefully exit. I think at a larger company with a larger marketing team, I would have been open to being an IC in another area. In fact, we talked about it, but the company and the team wasn’t set up for that. But that was just my experience! Everyone is different. For me, it was a great move.

text:
Yeeees!!!! This is perfect, <@U017WRJTKF1>! Very similar to the framework I use when I’m doing content/thought leadership strategy for clients. I literally started a strategy firm JUST BECAUSE after 7 years at a marketing agency, I had watched so many marketers focus on tactics without ever asking basic questions like “What is our goal?” and “What are the big ideas we want to own in the market?”

I have learned through a lot of trial and error that if you can get your team/boss/client to stop, back up, and spend some time defining your strategy (and that tactical FOCUS you touch on in your deck), you’ll have so much more success — or be able to pivot quickly if you’re not meeting your goals.
